metadata.title: A review of graphene-based nanomaterials for removal of antibiotics from aqueous environments

A review of graphene-based nanomaterials for removal of antibiotics from aqueous environments*
Xuandong Wang, Renli Yin, Lixi Zeng, Mingshan Zhu*
School of Environment, Jinan University, Guangzhou, 510632, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 19 March 2019 Received in revised form 5 June 2019 Accepted 18 June 2019 Available online 6 July 2019
Keywords: Graphene-based nanomaterials Antibiotics Adsorption Advanced oxidation processes Aqueous environments
* This paper has been recommended for acceptanc * Corresponding author.
E-mail address: zhumingshan@jnu.edu.cn (M. Zhu
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envpol.2019.06.067 0269-7491/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Antibiotics as emerging pharmaceutical pollutants have seriously not only threatened human life and animal health security, but also caused environmental pollution. It has drawn enormous attention and research interests in the study of antibiotics removal from aqueous environments. Graphene, an interesting one-atom-thick, 2D single-layer carbon sheet with sp2 hybridized carbon atoms, has become an important agent for removal of antibiotic, owing to its unique physiochemical properties. Recently, a variety of graphene-based nanomaterials (GNMs) are reported to efficiently remove antibiotics from aqueous solutions by different technologies. In this review, we summarize different structure and properties of GNMs for the removal of antibiotics by adsorption. Meanwhile, advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), such as photocatalysis, Fenton process, ozonation, sulfate radical and combined AOPs by the aid of GNMs are summarized. Finally, the opportunities and challenges on the future scope of GNMs for removal of antibiotics from aqueous environments are proposed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Antibiotics have been routinely used in keeping human and animal healthy. After penicillin was invented for antibacterial infection in 1942, a large number of antibiotics have been developed rapidly for infection treatment (Qiao et al., 2018). Widespread abuse of antibiotics makes large amounts of harmful antibiotic residues to be released into natural ecological environment (Shao et al., 2018). According to the statistics, there are more than 250 different antibiotics entities registered for treatment in human and veterinary medicine (Ahmed et al., 2015). China has the highest production and consumption of antibiotics in the world (Qiao et al., 2018). The production and consumption of antibiotics in 2013 was up to 2.48 105 tons and 1.62 105 tons, respectively, with the total emission of the 36 target antibiotics of 5.38 104 tons into water (46.0%) and soil environment (54.0%) (Liu et al., 2018; Zhang et al., 2015). Antibiotics could be classified to various types, on the basis of their chemical structure, medical mechanism and management regulation. One of the most popular classifications is dependent on their action mechanism, and Table S1 includes
e by Eddy Y. Zeng.
).
selected six types of antibiotics with details on their chemical structure, representative drugs and mechanism of action.
As known, antibiotics have been widely detected in ecosystem (Liu et al., 2018; Qiao et al., 2018). With the beginning of the production of antibiotics, the effluents enter into environment mainly from pharmaceutical industries, hospital wastes and veterinary drugs (Manzetti and Ghisi., 2014; Bagheri et al., 2016). Moreover, the unused or overdue antibiotics are directly discarded to municipal wastewater or deposited in landfills. Actually, most wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) cannot completely remove antibiotics, inducing that antibiotics get to surface water and even filter into ground water. Finally, the polluted water might flow into the drinking water treatment plants (DWTPs) thus transferring to drinking water for human. Another source of pollution is the veterinary antibiotics from the aquaculture, which directly release antibiotics to surfacewater, then to groundwater and finally turn to drinking water. Therefore, it is crying need to remove the antibiotics from aqueous environment.
From the past few decades, many materials have been reported to remove antibiotics from aqueous environments through adsorption or catalysis oxidation processes, such as natural zeolite (Braschi et al., 2010), bentonite (Genç and Dogan., 2013), activated carbon (AC) (Ahmed, 2017; Zhang et al., 2016a,b), carbon nanotubes (CNTs) (Ji et al., 2010), and biochar (BCs) (Peiris et al., 2017), etc. As the development of nanotechnology, and the demand of improving
adsorption capacity, nanomaterials have deeply penetrated into almost every field of science and technology, owing to their specific physical and chemical properties. In fact, various nanomaterials have been explored and used for the removal of antibiotics (Bagheri et al., 2016; Cerro-Lopez and M endez-Rojas., 2017), such as graphene-based nanomaterials (GNMs) (Jiang et al., 2019; Su arezIglesias et al., 2017), zero-valent iron nanoparticles (Cao et al., 2017; Chen et al., 2012), titatium oxide (Elmolla and Chaudhuri, 2010; Van Wieren et al., 2012), metal organic frameworks (MOFs) (Azhar et al., 2016; Azhar et al., 2017; Pi et al., 2018), polymer nanoparticles (Tan et al., 2013), and so on.
Among the referred nanomaterials, GNMs have been considered as emerging and high effective agents for removing antibiotics, due to their excellent physical and chemical properties, which offer new opportunities to improve the removal efficiency of antibiotics. The applications of GNMs in antibiotics are mainly through two approaches, including physical adsorption and chemical oxidation processes, especially for advanced oxidation processes (AOPs). Although some papers have referred to the method of GNMs in removal of antibiotics for water treatment and environmental remediation (Perreault et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2013; Yu et al., 2016), most of them were published before three years ago. Owing to the rapid development on the graphene-based materials for removal of antibiotics from aqueous environments, a timely review is urgent need to summarize recent works in last three-five years. Moreover, there is still no comprehensive article to summarize both physical adsorption and AOPs for antibiotics by GNMs in detail. Lastly, a critical review to systematically compare their pros and cons, and the role of graphene in these composites is still need. Therefore, in this review, the application of GNMs within last 5 years for the removal of antibiotics with adsorption and AOPs is summarized. The schematic illustration of this review is proposed in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2. Characteristics of GNMs
sections.text:
Graphene, the parent of all graphitic forms, is a 2D single layer of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms with the hexagonal aromatic rings
structure. On account of their unique intrinsic characters, such as high adsorption capacity, high electronic conductivity, excellent mechanical strength and good thermal stability, GNMs have drawn worldwide attention in both scientific and engineering fields. As the adjacent graphene layers in graphite are bound byweak van der Waals forces, graphene is initially obtained from mechanical exfoliation of graphite using adhesive tape. Geim and Novoselov obtained pristine single-layer graphene sheets through this facile approach, with their pioneering research on the electrical properties of graphene, which wined the Nobel Prize for Physics in 2010.
The desired application of graphene materials is often used in aqueous solution. However, the graphene is hydrophobic, so as to improve solubility and functions of graphene, various methods have been developed for modification of graphene and GNMs including graphene oxide (GO) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO). Generally, Hummers’ method is the most common way to synthesize GO from graphite (Hummers and Offeman., 1958). Therefore, GO is highly oxidized form of graphene, containing high density of oxygen functional groups (hydroxyl, carboxyl, carbonyl and epoxy). As to prepare rGO, it was based on the oxidation and exfoliation of GO, following by the chemical reduction with various reducing reagents, such as sodium borohydride (NaBH4), hydrazine (N2H4$H2O), hydroiodic acid (HI) and ascorbic acid (AA), etc. to obtain rGO nanosheets. The overview of structure and main properties of GNMs is shown in Table S2.
3. Adsorption of antibiotics by GNMs
3.1. Adsorption mechanism of antibiotics
Adsorption is considered to be a physical, simple and inexpensive approach for removal of antibiotics from aqueous environment. Removal of antibiotics through adsorption approach by GNMs mainly depends on the unique structure of graphene. Antibiotic molecules with aromatic rings can interact with graphene by different interactions. As shown in Fig. 2, there are four possible adsorption interactions between antibiotics and GNMs (Khan et al., 2017; Peng et al., 2016; Li et al., 2018; Yao et al., 2017), includingp-p interaction of antibiotics molecules with p electron of graphene aromatic ring (Zhuang et al., 2018; Lin et al., 2013), hydrogen bonding of antibiotics molecules with hydrogen ion from carboxyl or hydroxyl of GO (Yu et al., 2015; Yadav et al., 2018), hydrophobic
interaction of antibiotics molecules with hydrophobic groups of GNMs (Liu et al., 2016; Sun et al., 2018; Zhao et al., 2018) and electrostatic interactions of antibiotics molecules with carboxyl at different pH for cation attraction (pH＜pKa of antibiotics molecules) or cation attraction (pH＞pKa of antibiotics molecules) (Khan et al., 2017). Therefore, the aforementioned adsorption mechanisms could be used as important basis for explaining the antibiotic molecules react with GNMs.

sections.heading: 3.2. Adsorption of antibiotics on graphene
sections.text: Pristine graphene, GO, and rGO have exhibited moderate performance in the removal of antibiotics (Chen et al., 2014; Chen et al., 2015 Dong et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2016; Ma et al., 2017; Peng et al., 2016; Rostamian and Behnejad., 2018; Sun et al., 2018; Thakur and Kandasubramanian, 2019; Yadav et al., 2018; Yu et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2016a,b; Zhuang et al., 2018). The different chemical structures and groups of pristine graphene, GO and rGO, result in their difference on absorption capacity to antibiotics. Chen et al. (2014) demonstrated that the adsorption of sulfamethoxazole (SMX) on graphene could be affected by different functionalization, pH and ionic strength, and the maximum adsorption capacity of GNMs with various functional groups were as follow: pristine graphene (239.0mg g 1)> graphene-NH2 (40.6mg g 1)> graphene-COOH (20.5mg g 1)> graphene-OH (11.5mg g 1). Peng et al. (2016) compared the adsorption capacity of seven antibiotics with three kinds of carbon based materials including two biochar and graphene, of which graphene with the fastest adsorption speed and removal efficiency of antibiotics is up to 100%. The dominating adsorption is through the p-p interaction and auxiliary adsorption including hydrogen bonding interaction, electrostatic interaction, hydrophobic interaction and pore-filling. Wang et al. (2017a,b) used three kinds of GNMs, GO, rGO, and graphene nanoplatelet pastes (GNPs) as adsorbents for SMX removal. Oxygen-containing functional groups with less Csp2 sites for p-p stacking and graphene wrinkles with less accessible flat sites for adsorption, resulting inweaker adsorption capacity of SMX on GO and GNPs, respectively. The alkali-activation method motivated oxygen-containing functional groups synthesized activated graphene adsorbents, which is conductive to increase the specific surface and improve adsorption capacity for the removal of ciprofloxacin (CIP) (Yu et al., 2015) and TC (Ma et al., 2017). Meanwhile, different adsorption behavior of TC, doxycycline (DOC) and CIP onto GO nanosheets in aqueous solution was evaluated (Rostamian and Behnejad., 2018). The maximum adsorption capacity (qmax) of antibiotics was ranged as follow: CIP[DOC> TC. Complex interactions between antibiotics and GNMs are determined by both the intrinsic adsorption capacity of GNMs and transfer processes of antibiotics in aqueous environments (Zhang et al., 2016a,b).

sections.heading: 3.3. Adsorption of antibiotics on graphene-based nanocomposites
sections.text:
To enhance the removal efficiency, various graphene-based nanocomposites were also developed to optimize the properties of graphene adsorbents, such as GO/TiO2 (Li et al., 2017a,b,c), Polymer/GO (Chen et al., 2016; Gonzalez et al., 2018), GO/biochar (Huang et al., 2017a,b), Sodium alginate/GO (Yu et al., 2016) and magnetic graphene nanocomposites (MGNPs) (Hu et al., 2016; Huang et al., 2017a,b; Kerkez-Kuyumcu et al., 2016; Li et al., 2017a,b,c; Li et al., 2018; Lin et al., 2013; Miao et al., 2019; Mohammadi Nodeh et al., 2018; Shi and Ye, 2015; Tan et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2016; Wu et al., 2016; Yang et al., 2017a,b; Yu et al., 2017). The removal capacity and mechanism of different GNMs for antibiotics are shown in Table 1.
In various GNMs, theMGNPs enrich and separate antibiotic from
water by using an external magnetic field, which are also easy recyclable for the regeneration of adsorbents. The preparations of MGNPs as adsorbents are mainly divided into two approaches: one pot and two steps. Miao et al. (2019) prepared magnetic graphene oxide by one pot solvothermal method at 190 C. The maximum removal efficiencies of TC, chlortetracycline (CTC), and oxytetracycline (OTC) were 141.4, 303.9, and 289.9mg g 1, respectively. Lin et al. (2013) synthesized graphene oxide functionalized with magnetic nanoparticles (GO/MNPs) by two-step method. The adsorption performance of GO/MNPs for removal of tetracycline antibiotics (TCs) was comparative, such as TC (39.1mg g 1), OTC (45.0mg g 1), CTC (42.6mg g 1) and DOC (35.5mg g 1). The adsorption mechanism of TCs on GO/MNPs was mainly through pp interaction.

sections.heading: 3.4. Adsorption of antibiotics on 3D graphene gel
sections.text:
The major limit for 2D GNMs application as adsorbent is their relative low adsorption capacity compare with 3D architectures. Thus, 3D hierarchical architectures have caught great attention as potential strategies (Shen et al., 2014). A large number of research has been studied to make the fabrication of 3D GNMs. In general, unique porous structure of 3D GNMswith high specific surface area enable them to be ideal agents for the removal of antibiotics from aqueous solution with excellent adsorption capability and recyclability (Ma et al., 2015; Shan et al., 2018; Song et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2017a,b; Yao et al., 2017; Zhao et al., 2018; Zhuang et al., 2015).
The precursor of GO results in 3D GNMs architectures through self-assembly, template-mediated, and other synthetic approaches (Fang et al., 2015). For example, 3D network microstructure of cellulose nanofibril/graphene oxide hybrid (CNF/GO) aerogel was successfully prepared by a facile ultrasonication method (Yao et al. (2017)). 21 kinds of antibiotics were studied and adsorption mechanism might be p-p interaction, p-p interaction, hydrogen bonding, and electrostatic attraction. Song et al. (2019) in-situ generatedMnO2 on three-dimensional graphene (3DG). 3DG/MnO2 could efficiently remove TC via adsorption and degradation, owing to the synergistic effect of MnO2 and 3DG. It was demonstrated that the reaction speed of TC with 3DG/MnO2 was related with temperature and pH value, the reaction speed became faster with the rising of temperature, and increased with the decrease of pH value.

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption of antibiotics by separation membrane
sections.text:
GNMs have attracted great attention for nanofiltration (NF) separation membranes in water desalination and purification, sewage treatment, dialysis and gases separation, owing to their unique laminar structure and excellent physicochemical properties (Liu et al., 2015). GNMs NF membranes are also demonstrated to be with improved performances in removing antibiotics (Liu et al., 2017; Yang et al., 2018; Yang et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2018).
Liu et al. (2017) produced a series of hybrid carbon based freestanding and flexible membranes via vacuum filtration method, including pure GO, activated carbon (AC), carbon nanotube (CNT), GO/AC, CNT/AC and GO/CNT hybrids membrane. Among them, GO/ AC membrane exhibited the highest adsorption capacity, with the adsorption capacity of TCH at 449.0mg g 1, owing to strong interactions of GO/AC with TCH through p-p stacking, hydrogen bonding, electrostatic interaction, and van der Waals forces. Yang et al. (2018) developed a 3D all-carbon NF membrane of functionalized PDDA-MWCNTs/GO with the thickness of 4.26 mm and high adsorption efficiency for TCH of 99.2%. High adsorption performance could attribute to the synergistic effect of hydrophobic interaction, and electrostatic interaction between antibiotic molecules and the membrane.

sections.heading: 4. Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) for removal of antibiotics
sections.text:
Despite the high removal efficiency of antibiotics by adsorption techniques, they still have intrinsic drawback of being nondestructive, and just making the antibiotics from water on adsorbent without elimination, which may cause a secondary pollution. It is significant to develop superior technologies to completely break down the antibiotics. AOPs are efficient ways to make use of radicals to degrade pollutants to nonhazardous materials during water treatment processes. GNMs have been considered effective for the removal of antibiotics from aqueous solution by separation processes like adsorption process, membrane process. Various AOPs were developed, such as photocatalysis (Anirudhan and Deepa, 2017; Appavu et al., 2018; Bai et al., 2017; Cao et al., 2016; Chakraborty et al., 2018; Hu et al., 2016; Jo et al., 2017; Karaolia et al., 2018; Priya et al., 2016a,b; Shabani et al., 2019; Shan et al., 2017; Shaniba et al., 2018; Song et al., 2016; Tang et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2017; Zhu et al., 2017a, b), Fenton process (Wang et al., 2017; Wan and Wang, 2017; Zhuang et al., 2019), ozonation (Yin et al., 2017), sulfate radical based oxidation (Chen et al., 2018a,b; Cherifi et al., 2019; Kang et al., 2019), and combined AOPs, such as electro-Fenton process (Divyapriya et al., 2018; Li et al., 2017a,b,c; Mi et al., 2019), photoelectrocatalysis (Kadeer et al., 2019), sonophotocatalysis (Reheman et al., 2019; Vinesh et al., 2019) and photocatalytic-ozonation (Sheydaei et al., 2018), etc. The advantage and disadvantage of these methods for the removal of antibiotics are summarized in Table S3. Various AOPs supported by GNMs are
shown in Fig. 3, and these AOPs approaches on GNMs for removal of antibiotics are list in Table 2. The works of these AOPs are described below.

sections.heading: 4.1. Photocatalysis
sections.text:
Photocatalysis refers to an approach of using light as a source of energy, and photocatalysts absorb photons from the light to motivate and accelerate catalysis reaction rate. This approach is considered to be a high effective way to degrade pollutants avoiding secondary pollution. GNMs photocatalysts possess stronger photocatalytic degradation capacity than the non-graphene based ones, because GNMs have higher adsorption property by their large specific surface area and ability to inhibit recombination of photoexcited electron-hole pairs, and with excellent visible photocatalytic activity (Anku et al., 2019). In recent years, various types of GNMs photocatalysts have been widely reported to degrade antibiotics from aqueous solution, such as TiO2 (Cao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2019; Hu et al., Jo et al., 2017; Karaolia et al., 2018; Shaniba et al., 2018; Song et al., 2016; Tang et al., 2018), BiOCl (Priya et al., 2016a,b; Shabani et al., 2019), BiVO4 (Appavu et al., 2018), ZnS (Bai et al., 2017), ZnTe (Chakraborty et al., 2018), ZnO (Anirudhan and Deepa, 2017) MOF (Shabani et al., 2019), Ag/Bi2WO6/GO (Dong et al., 2018), WO3 (Zhu et al., 2017a, b), g-C3N4 (Wang et al., 2017a,b), g-C3N4/BiVO4/rGO (Jiang et al., 2017), etc.
As an example, TiO2 is a classical photocatalyst for degradation of antibiotics, due to its high catalytic activity, good physical and chemical stability, nontoxicity and low cost (Bhanvase et al., 2016). When TiO2 was irradiated at a wavelength shorter than the band gap of TiO2 (3.2 eV), water could be photocatalyzed to producing electrons and holes, according to the following reactions (Bhanvase et al., 2016):
TiO2 þhn /e þhþ, (1)
O2þhþ /O2 , (2)
OH þ e / OH, (3)
The resultant hþ, O2 and OH (excellent oxidizing agents) then

For example, Jo et al. (2017) synthesized spinel-like Co3O4/TiO2/ GO heterojunction nanocomposites as photocatalyst via sol-gel and hydrothermal routes. In this work, the photocatalytic performance of Co3O4/TiO2 and Co3O4/TiO2/GO nanocomposites were assessed under simulated solar irradiation, the 2.0 wt% Co3O4/TiO2/GO photocatalyst was demonstrated to have higher photocatalysis activity for degradation of oxytetracycline (OTC) and Congo Red (CR) than those without GO photocatalysts with an enhancement of 15e20%. GO may play a role of promoting photogenic charge separation. As is shown in Fig. 4, the photoexcited electrons the conduction band (CB) of Co3O4 and TiO2, reacting with O2 to produce superoxide radicals (O2 -), while valence band (VB) of Co3O4 photooxidize water to generate hydroxyl radicals (OH ). It was demonstrated that the holes, OH and O2 - were important pathways for oxidative photodegradation of pollutants.

sections.heading: 4.2. Fenton/fenton-like process
sections.text:
Fenton/Fenton-like process is one of the traditional AOPs, which bases on the ferrous ions (Fe2þ, Fe3þ) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) for generating hydroxyl radicals ( OH) in aqueous medium, which has a high oxidation potential for degradation of pollutants. GNMs
are effective for the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide and generation of hydroxyl radicals. Furthermore, GNMs loading of iron or iron oxides could significantly improve the catalytic activity by the Fenton process. The reactions are as follow:
Fe2þ þ H2O2 / Fe3þþ OH þ OH (4)
Fe3þ þ H2O2 / Fe2þþ Hþþ HO2 (5)
HO2 þ H2O2 / H2O þ OH þ O2 (6)
It has been reported that some kinds of GNMs with Fe catalysts were used in Fenton-like process for removal of antibiotics, such as Fe3O4eMn3O4/rGO (Wang et al., 2017a,b), Ce0/Fe0-rGO (Wan and Wang, 2017), a-FeOOH/rGO (Zhuang et al., 2019).
Wan and Wang (2017) synthesized Fe3O4eMn3O4/rGO nanocomposites via polyol process and impregnation method, and they showed high catalytic performance for degrading of sulfamethazine (SMT) (about 98.0%) as heterogeneous Fenton-like catalysts in aqueous solution. It was found that hydroxyl radicals ($OH) was the main active species on Fe3O4eMn3O4/rGO hybrid catalyst surface. Zhuang et al. (2019) synthesized ethylene glycol (EG) mediated aFeOOH/rGO hydrogels by a facile method. It was demonstrated that EG could enhance the p-Fe interaction (between graphene and a-
FeOOH) and the electrons could be transferred through p-p interactions (between TC and graphene), resulting in enhanced degradation efficiency of TC.

sections.heading: 4.3. Ozonation
sections.text:
Ozonation, the application of ozone molecules (O3), is another traditional type of advanced oxidation processes (at basic pH) that has been used in wastewater treatments (Liu et al., 2015). Ozonation is a non-selective method induced by O3 or highly reactive $OH, and broke toxic organic pollutants into smaller harmless molecules. GO is an oxidized form of graphene containing abundant oxygen functional groups on its carbon lattice. The delocalized electrons from the zigzag edges of graphene have a high chemical activity, which could promote the O3 to generate radicals for improving the degradation efficiency of contaminant (Yin et al., 2017).
Yin et al. (2017) synthesized heteroatoms (N and P) doped graphene oxides (NGO, PGO) nanocomposites, and they were used for the catalytic ozonation removal of sulfamethoxazole (SMX) (Fig. 5A). NGO and PGO exhibited significant degradation efficiency of SMX was 95.0% and 99.0%, respectively, which was much higher than ozone alone process (62.0%). The proposed mechanism of ozonation of SMX on NGO and PGO is shown in Fig. 5B. The lone electrons such as ketonic groups on Lewis basic sites have an extraordinary potential for the redox reaction. Therefore, the NGO and PGO materials are considered to play a dominant role for ozonation to generate more active radicals and sites for enhancing the catalysis of ozonation.

sections.heading: 4.4. Sulfate radical-based AOPs
sections.text:
Recently, sulfate radical-based AOPs have attracted great interests owing to their unique advantages, such as wide pH range, high oxidation potential, selectivity and efficiency to oxidize antibiotics with aromatic ring or unsaturated bonds. Sulfate radicalbased AOPs could produce high reactive sulfate radicals mainly by activation of PDS and peroxymonosulfate (PMS) in aqueous solution. Therefore, sulfate radicals have the capacity to remove the antibiotics efficiently (Wang and Wang, 2018). GNMs were generally used as important supporting medium for the generation of sulfate radicals (Nidheesh, 2017). GNMs supported metal oxides such as CoO, Fe2O3, MnO2, etc. exhibited efficiently enhancing catalytic activity of persulfate (PS) and PMS. The defects of GNMs
such as vacancies, zigzag or armchair edges, and so on significantly activate PMS with more efficient electron transfer, extended OeO bond, and higher adsorption energy (Duan et al., 2016). GNMs could donate electrons to PS or PMS to generate the reactive radicals the reaction as follow (Wang and Wang, 2018).
S2O82- þ e /SO4 .- þ SO42- (7)
HSO5 þ e /SO4.- þ OH (8)
For instance, Chen et al. (2018a,b) synthesized CoFe2O4-GO nanocomposites with uniformly decorating CoFe2O4 nanoparticles on GO by one pot hydrothermal method. CoFe2O4-GO nanocomposites were demonstrated to have better reactivity than that of CoFe2O4 for producing sulfate radicals through the decomposition of PMS. Degradation of antibiotics in the CoFe2O4/PMS system might be a radical process, meanwhile, nonradical process are dominant in the CoFe2O4-GO/PMS system. Chen et al. (2018a,b) fabricated nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) through thermal annealing of GO and urea was used to activate PMS for SAM degradation. It was illustrated that NG600 (NG prepared at 600 C) to be a good PMS activator with high removal efficiency of SAM 100% within 50min.

sections.heading: 4.5. Combined AOPs methods
sections.text:
In order to enhance the removal capacity for antibiotics by GNMs, a series of combined AOPs methods were studied (Fig. 6), such as Electro-Fenton (Li et al., 2017a,b,c; Mi et al., 2019; Divyapriya et al., 2018), PEC (Kadeer et al., 2019), Sonophotocatalysis (Reheman et al., 2019; Vinesh et al., 2019), Photocatalyticozonation (Sheydaei et al., 2018; Checa et al., 2019).
Divyapriya et al. (2018) functionalized graphene based graphite felt electrode with ferrocene and studied electro-Fenton oxidation process of CIP in neutral pH condition with >99.9% CIP removal (Fig. 6A). The electrode is reusable after five cycles in removal efficiency with no significant change. Kadeer et al. (2019) synthesized rGO/AgCl QDs by ultrasonic-assisted method, and investigated their PEC performance for the removal of TC, with the highest degradation efficiency (85.2%), which was much better than single photocatalysis (39.2%) or electrocatalysis (20.7%), respectively. The photoelectrocatalytic mechanism for coupling of AgCl QDs and rGO is shown in Fig. 6B. The synthesized rGO/AgCl QDs could effectively promote the separation of electron-hole pairs as the shorter charge
transfer pathway of AgCl QDs, and exhibit the better photocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic activity. Furthermore, mechanical ultrasound could remarkably improve the mass transfer rate of catalysts in liquid phase, and keep homogeneity of the reaction solution for photocatalysis. Vinesh et al. (2019) fabricated Au/BeTiO2/rGO nanocomposites by facile hydrothermal method and exhibited high degradation rate with the synergic effect of ultrasound and photocatalysis. The mechanism for sonophotocatalytic degradation of TC with the aid of Au/BeTiO2/rGO nanocomposites is shown in Fig. 6C. GNMs supported catalysts could also be used for application of photocatalytic ozonation. Sheydaei et al. (2018) fabricated NeTiO2/GO/Ti grid sheet through electrophoretic deposition method. The removal capacity for degradation of cefixime was evaluated using NeTiO2/GO catalyst under visible light photocatalytic-ozonation process in aqueous solution (Fig. 6D), resulting in removal efficiency of cefixime up to 80.0%, which is much higher than that of individual approach, such as physical adsorption (17.0%), photocatalysis (29.0%) and ozonation (51.0%), respectively.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and perspective
sections.text:
This review summarized different structural types of GNMs, such as graphene, GO, rGO, GO nanocomposites, 3D graphene oxide gel, graphene membranes for the removal antibiotics by physical adsorption and AOPs. GNMs are successfully used for the removal of prominent antibiotics, which adsorb onto GNMs mainly through p-p interaction, electrostatic interaction, hydrophobic interaction and hydrogen bonding. Then, AOPs methods for removing antibiotics, such as photocatalysis, Fenton process, ozonation, sulfate radical and combined AOPs have been studied and discussed in details. Whereas, before we explore all the potential of them for real environmental applications, there are still have plenty of challenges and difficulties to be overcome. Herein, wewould like to put forward some suggestions that might help for the future water treatment by GNMs.
(1) Although there are a lot of advantages for GNMs, it is difficult to recycle and regenerate them. It may lead to a potential secondary pollution when they are discarded to environment. Therefore, it is crucial to investigate the physicochemical behavior of GNMs in the ecological environment, to evaluate their behavior such as aggregation, deposition, adsorption, toxicity and migration in ecosystem. How to develop green, harmless and recycling disposal ways for antibiotics is an important research direction in the future.
(2) High cost and reusability are the two main problems associated with GNMs. It is necessary to produce reusable GNMs to reduce the price. Similarly, the preparation and purification of GNMs are an exhausting and time consuming process. Therefore, high cost and reusability are some of the unresolved problems associated with GNMs, which can hinder the use of GNMs in the environmental pollution management. The development of effective and low-cost regeneration techniques and advanced equipment, large-scale may supply chains for the continuous production GNMswith high yield and low cost.
(3) It is complex in the actual aqueous environments, there are wide variety of pollutants not just antibiotics. Moreover, the types of antibiotics are also not the same. As the coexistence of multiple pollutants in the aqueous environments, the design and development of the GNMs with high efficiency and selectivity, is one of the future research directions.
(4) Another limitation for GNMs widely use for removal of antibiotics is that they might bring second health and
environmental pollution risks. Therefore, it is a great need to synthesize stable GNMs and control the leakage into environment during water treatment. Meanwhile, they also should be properly disposed of after the treatment. In aword, GNMs should be used in economic and environmentally friendly ways for safe and nontoxic application.

metadata.abstractText: Antibiotics as emerging pharmaceutical pollutants have seriously not only threatened human life and animal health security, but also caused environmental pollution. It has drawn enormous attention and research interests in the study of antibiotics removal from aqueous environments. Graphene, an interesting one-atom-thick, 2D single-layer carbon sheet with sp2 hybridized carbon atoms, has become an important agent for removal of antibiotic, owing to its unique physiochemical properties. Recently, a variety of graphene-based nanomaterials (GNMs) are reported to efficiently remove antibiotics from aqueous solutions by different technologies. In this review, we summarize different structure and properties of GNMs for the removal of antibiotics by adsorption. Meanwhile, advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), such as photocatalysis, Fenton process, ozonation, sulfate radical and combined AOPs by the aid of GNMs are summarized. Finally, the opportunities and challenges on the future scope of GNMs for removal of antibiotics from aqueous environments are proposed. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
